ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to use R for data analysis and good practices for Sociology data research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: sometimes a little bit too hard for students who have just finished introductory statistics course

One of the strengths was the about of hands-on help from the TFs. They were a great resource and were always available to help with any issues I came across. The main weakness I saw was how the problem sets could have been used more effectively. Instead of being key moments in learning some of them were quite easy and some were optional. Overall they were quite useful when there was a problem set but they missed out assessing some of the topics I would have found more useful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I was the only undergrad taking this course this year. I found it to be a great way to learn data analysis in a non-stats way. I came in knowing very little about R and at the end was able to do a fine piece of research using a dataset. If you are a sociology major thinking about using data this is the course for you.
